💕 Don't stress. Just do your best 💕

Stress is our body’s automated response, commonly known as the “fight or flight” response, of being under too much mental or emotional pressure.

When you are stressed, your body releases hormones such as adrenaline and cortisol. Cortisol, the main human stress hormone, raises blood sugar by releasing stored glucose. High cortisol levels can lead to persistent high blood sugar, which can cause Type 2 diabetes.

In general, though, there are several everyday things you can do to try to lower your stress and cortisol levels:

😴 Quality sleep: Decreases cortisol levels and restores balance to your body's systems. Try to get between seven to nine hours of sleep a night.

🤸 Exercise regularly: Regular exercise helps improve sleep quality, which can help lower cortisol levels over time.

🤔 Limit stressful thinking patterns: Being aware of your thinking pattern, breathing, heart rate and other signs of tension helps you recognize stress when it begins and can help you prevent it from becoming worse.

🌬️ Practice deep breathing exercises: Controlled breathing helps stimulate your parasympathetic nervous system, your “rest and digest” system, which helps lower cortisol levels.

😂 Laugh: Laughing promotes the release of endorphins and suppresses cortisol. Participating in hobbies and fun activities can also promote feelings of well-being, which may lower your cortisol levels.

Some sorts of stress (in small amounts) can motivate you to perform better, encourage growth, and give meaning to your life. Differentiating between the good and bad stress though, is crucial to living a balanced, healthy life.

#nationalstressawarenessday

Interested in art-based exercises that provide a mental break, foster focus and energize the mind!?🧠

Guests will lobe this online, interactive, hands-on #professionalDevelopment workshop, designed for teachers and wellness facilitators who want to learn cognitive psychology and neuroscience.

Link in bio for tickets!

✨💖 DO HOLIDAY LIGHTS SPARK HAPPINESS? ✨💖

You betchya! Lighting helps us to feel more energetic and lifts our mood. It is a known fact that lighting has a direct impact on our brain and our hormone balance via the retina in our eyes.👀

The lights can also trigger dopamine, the 'feel good' chemical in the brain. With these bright experiences with lights, we do have the physiological response from the nervous system that helps make us more alert, more aware, and can bring about these feelings of happiness.

Hit the link in our bio to take a stroll through #SparkleSparkle starting December 1, and get lit with Spark this holiday season!

A WIN OUT OF THIS WORLD!🍦🚀🌌

Have you had a chance to try the new #JamesWebb ice cream from the Astronaut Ice Cream café!? Not only is it an award winning telescope, but now, the James Webb is an award winning cone available only at TELUS Spark!

The #JamesWebbIceCream has just won the Food and Beverage 'Best New Menu Item' from IAAPA, which recognizes significant achievement in the global attractions industry, making the James Webb Ice Cream cone the best new treat this side of the sun.

Spark is so proud of its very own in-house food and beverage team that ideated and created this winning ice cream. Led by Victor Bustamante and Robin Rong, there will surely be more cool treats on the horizon.

On the tenth day of Twinkle, Spark Science asked of me...TO GIVE!

#GivingTuesday is a global movement unleashing the power of people and organizations to transform their communities and the world.

From amplifying fundraising missions, rallying volunteers for a cause, or just helping out a neighbour in need, there are hundreds of different ways to participate in Giving Tuesday.

Spark is aiming to rise as a science beacon, community hub, and source of inspiration for youth and all those looking for a unifying place to celebrate science! By donating to Calgary's only science centre, you help expand educational programming and hands-on learning opportunities for students and youth from every corner of Calgary.

From now until December 31, every gift to Spark will be TRIPLED in size thanks to @mcelhanney and the Nicholls family, our generous matching donors!

Your gift, however big, means more access to the science centre for those who simply can’t afford to come.

Hit the link in our bio to donate today!

🧠The chemicals your brain releases when you feel joy are similar to the ones that trigger you to feel gratitude and love.💕

Scientists have discovered that much of happiness is in our personal control. Only 10% is determined by life circumstances. Most is determined by genetics, (about 50%). BUT, the other 40% is based on what we do everyday.

Happiness and joy results in neurophysiological changes that are associated with less chronic pain and better physical health. When you are joyous, dopamine levels increase, blood sugar levels decrease, and your connection with the world around you, brightens.

🏒HOCKEY OF COURSE!🏒

Beginning January 13 to March 12, TELUS Spark will be home to HOCKEY - Faster than Ever, proudly presented by @timhortons.

The physics of hockey is everywhere, quite interesting, and even a little intense.

The velocity and force with which a puck can be shot in an ice-hockey game, can get up to well over 100mph. When a player flexes, or bends his stick, energy is stored in the blade. The rotation of a slap shot causes the stored energy to release and transfer to the puck. Energy goes from player to stick, then from stick to puck.

Visitors will get a front row seat to the science behind hockey, the origins and culture of the game, jump on the replica rink in the 'Science Lab', and see real game-used gear from hockey's biggest stars.

HOCKEY – Faster Than Ever is an exhibition produced and toured internationally by Flying Fish incollaboration with The Montreal Science Centre and supported by the NHL and NHLPA.

A bill put forward by Senator Mary Jane McCallum, to recognize #NationalRibbonSkirtDay, has received Royal Assent and is now an act of parliament!

McCallum was inspired to create the bill after a young Saskatchewan girl named #IsabellaKulak was shamed for wearing a ribbon skirt during a formal school event in 2021. Now, every year on Jan. 4, National Ribbon Skirt Day provides an opportunity for Canadians to educate themselves and recognize the importance of Indigenous traditions and cultures.

The ribbon skirt is honoured as a centuries-old spiritual symbol of womanhood,  resilience, survival and identity. It represents reclaiming identity, and wearing that identity proudly.

🔥HEATERS GUNNA HEAT🔥

Ever wondered why your mouth feels on fire when those spicy drinks and food hit?

It is because a chemical component called capsaicin which is released as a fine spray when you bite into foods that contain it. Heat receptors then get triggered in the skin, which TRICK the nervous system into thinking the body is overheating. In response, your brain cranks up all of body's cool down processes. Hot wing sweats anyone?

What about alcohol and spicy foods? Together, do they make it a mean heat?

Alcohol activates those same pain receptors that capsaicin does, and matched to high capsaicin in the food, they actually end up amplify each other. The bitter becomes more bitter and the spicy more spicy.

So why do some people enjoy spicy foods? During the consumption of capsaicin, our bodies also release a natural painkiller — endorphins — one of the "happy hormones" which cause feelings of euphoria.

Are you a gluten for punishment in the form of spicy food and drink? Drop your fav spicy treats in the comments.

#InternationalHotandSpicyFoodDay

All these drives full of sorted data. It's information in formation!

Server rooms are enclosed spaces that provide a central point for organizations to manage their network server resources - And this is a peek at the #InfinityDometheatre server room. 

The servers support the operational needs of the dome, and provide an environment where computer equipment can safely operate in one location, so that playback and other networking activities are made easier and more effective.

This specific setup consists of 8 Image generators, producing 70 million pixel, with a combined 72 Terabytes of data storage - Each one running at 3.8Ghz processing speed, producing 8k graphics at 60 frames per second!

January 16-25 Spark is updating the Dome's system to the newest version of SkyExplorer software, designed in France by @rsa_cosmos.

The design of these environments must also take into consideration network connectivity and power, room temperature control and ventilation, room and rack security, and fire and seismic protection.

#FunFact: There is a stack of fans, taller than the computers themselves, that keeps the room from overheating.

💕CAN YOU HEARTLY BELIEVE IT!?💕

The feeling of love doesn't actually occur in the heart, at least scientifically. Instead, it happens in the brain 🧠 (specifically, a part of the brain called the amygdala) when hormones (oxytocin, dopamine, adrenaline, testosterone, estrogen, and vasopressin) are released, it creates a mix of feelings: euphoria, pleasure or bonding.

High levels of dopamine and a related hormone, norepinephrine, are released during this attraction. These chemicals can make one giddy, energetic, and euphoric, even leading to decreased appetite and insomnia – which means you actually can be so “in love” that you can't eat and can't sleep.

So why is the heart associated with love?❤️

One theory is that the heart shape comes from the shape of the leaves of a now-extinct plant called silphium, which was considered a key component of a love potion in the time of the Romans. Another theory is that St. Valentine used the symbol when arranging secret marriages.

People might also associate the heart with strong emotions like love because when you are excited to see someone, the heart can beat faster, and the increase in heartbeat is noticed, not what is happening in the brain.

#valentines

😲 FEAST YOUR EYES ON THIS CORONA!😲

It’s not beer. It’s Aurora!

When auroral displays are overhead, you will be closer to it, so you get a totally different perspective. More colours can be seen with the naked eye, and they will be very bright, structured and fast! This is called a coronal aurora or corona.

Coronas are some of the most spectacular auroral phenomenons, but they are rare, and usually only happen at high latitudes during substorms; sporadically and very elusively.

When a corona explodes, the middle rapidly flickers bright green and pinks, and the whole structure will seemingly flow as the colours replace one  another.

Enjoy these incredible shots, captured by @rj_daroza this past Monday, as the #northernlights danced above the #Alberta skyline.💕💚

This awe-inspiring and thought-provoking meld of art and science, draws guests in and distorts reality, giving new light and perspective to the mundane. Artist Installation feature: Virata Rupa
By: Matt Elson
@the_infinity_boxes

Virata Rupa allows guests to peer inside the ornate windows of The Infinity Boxes to encounter dreamlike wonderlands of playfully altered perception. Appearing in elaborate, custom-built boxes adorned with abstract oil paintings, these artworks by Matt Elson combine mirrors, light, colour, and viewer interactions to produce seemingly limitless fields of reflections.

🎉 WONDERSPACES, AN INTERACTIVE AUDIO-VISUAL FEAST FOR THE WHOLE FAMILY, ARRIVES AT TELUS SPARK SCIENCE CENTRE TODAY! 🎉

Guests of all ages can finally see what happens when the worlds of science and art merge into one mesmerizing experience.🖌️🦠🎨🧬

Wonderspaces, a new long-term exhibition making its international debut at TELUS Spark Science Centre, is located in the former Earth & Sky Gallery and features nine unique and thought-provoking interactive art installations that play with movement, music, light, colour, optical illusions, digital projection and storytelling.

Founded in 2016 and based in Los Angeles, @wonderspaces is an organization that partners with artists to make art more accessible to everyone. They operate shows in cities across the United States, from Scottsdale, Arizona to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; Austin, Texas; and San Diego, California. Spark is the first science centre in the world to feature a Wonderspaces travelling exhibition, featuring artists whose work is unavailable anywhere else in Canada.

✨💥 Imagine a gender equal world. A world free of bias, stereotypes, and discrimination. A world that's diverse, equitable, and inclusive. A world where difference is valued and celebrated. Together we can forge women's equality. Collectively we can all #EmbraceEquity.💥✨

From iconic historical figures and integral women in science like #HenriettaLacks, her cells are the source of the HeLa cell line, one of the most important cell lines in medical research, to scientists of today like @NASA engineer @dajae.monae using hip hop to make math and science more accessible to young people. Women all around the world are challenging gender norms and creating a future filled with inclusion, equity, creativity and strength.💪

Women are very underrepresented in science. Supporting women in science and technology not only helps to foster positive environments in innovations that meets women’s needs, but it also promotes gender equality within spaces. Being underrepresented in STEAM education and careers, remains a major barrier to participation in tech design and too often forces women out of the digital spaces they occupy.

Together, let's Imagine and work toward a gender equal world. A world free of bias, stereotypes, and discrimination. A world that's diverse, equitable, and inclusive. A world where difference is valued and celebrated. #EmbraceEquity

At Spark, it is an honour and a privilege to have so many strong people who identify as women, bravely and confidently forging paths through science and tech!

 Happy #InternationalWomensDay🎉

The newest digital immersion experience, Sacred Defenders Of The Universe, opens March 23 at TELUS Spark. 

@JustinJackBear and @Earl_Benallie; two Indigenous creatives out of Vancouver, BC, wrote the story of Sacred Defenders of the Universe.  The story of tells how The Great Conflict gave birth to four superheroes, known as the Four Sacred Elements: Water (Aqueous), Fire (Embers), Earth (Terra) and Wind (Aireus). 

“Jack Bear” is a trade name honouring all of Justin's cultures, as a proud member of the Garden River First Nation in Ontario. He works in the film, entertainment and media industry, supporting and producing original Indigenous stories from across Turtle Island - breathing life into the stories he brings to the screen, as sacred defender #Aireus does, for all living things.

Earl Benallie is part of the Ktunaxa and Navajo nations, and for more than three decades, has been writing in personal journals, creating poems and telling stories. He successfully launched his own company called, Rain-Cycle: Irrigation systems and Solutions, to promote rainwater harvesting and its benefits. Earl hopes to install rainwater harvesting systems all over First Nation communities to help offset their demand for freshwater shortages.

With his extensive water knowledge in the irrigation industry and a unique cultural connection to Rainwater Harvesting, Earl is a ringer for sacred defender #Aqueous. 

Sacred Defenders of the Universe  was created and built by TELUS Spark Science Centre. This Indigenous-led story was created by Justin Jack Bear and Earl Benallie, animated by a team of Indigenous and non-Indigenous artists, and produced in partnership with @supply_and_demand_studio

💞 NEW AT TELUS SPARK AND WRAPPED WITH LOVE 💞

@Themossbagproject.

Located in the Creative Kids Museum (CKM), on the first floor, guests can now enjoy a permanent moss bag installation as a part of the newly renovated infant section.

For centuries, the moss bag has been used by Indigenous peoples to keep babies snugly wrapped in a warm, womb-like environment that makes the baby feel safe and have a better sleep. From ornate to incredibly functional, @themossbagproject's waspison are beaded and story rich and now, a story told at Spark.

Moss bags, traditionally lined with freshly-gathered sphagnum moss, are known to have medicinal properties that make it an ideal diaper. Antiseptic and absorbent, the moss keeps the baby dry and rash-free.

With all the generous donations by shopping for #mossbags, @themossbagproject has been able to create scholarships for Indigenous mothers and Two-Spirit parents that are on their post-secondary journey.

Enjoy the beautiful new addition to the CKM.💙

This project was brought to life by a fantastic team including @fiddlerkissconsulting, @re.sci.circle, @angelastinson, @silviamcguigan , @eirinberns, @pamelatodd and @amy_elee, with original artwork by @keegan_art.

There are two reasons why you should never drink toilet water.
Number one. And number two. 🤣

This specific toilet at TELUS Spark Science Centre is a different story though - You can be like @Kennevo and drink away from this porcelain potty - clean and fresh water is all you'll find.🚰

But right now, according to https://www.worldwaterday.org/, we are seriously off-track to meet the Sustainable Development Goal of clean water and sanitation for all by 2030. Billions of people and countless schools, businesses, healthcare centres, farms and factories don’t have the safe water and toilets they need.

This World Water Day, Spark actions everyone to think about how your family, school and community can make a difference by changing how water is consumed and managed. Do your part to accelerate change to solve the water and sanitation crisis.

Water affects us all, so everyone needs to take action.

#WorldWaterDay 🌎💦 🌎

💥💪💫 SACRED DEFENDERS OF THE UNIVERSE IS NOW OPEN AT TELUS SPARK💥💪💫

After a long anticipated wait, and countless hours of hard work, guests can finally meet the four Indigenous superheroes - Aqueous, Embers, Terra and Aireus - and follow them as they seek to bring back the balance of humility and respect for the land, in the newest digital immersion experience at Spark!

Sacred Defenders Of The Universe is an incredible immersive story that allows visitors to interact with each of the digital elements, creating waves and wind with their fingertips, igniting senses with sparks and fire, and growing plants and mycelium in front of their eyes.

Discover Indigenous science through the Circle of Life, the four elements and directions, and key words in local Indigenous languages as the 3,000 square-foot space flows through a vibrant floor-to-ceiling graphic novel journey.

This Indigenous-led story comes from the minds of @justinjackbear and @earl_benallie, created and built by TELUS Spark Science Centre. Sacred Defenders Of The Universe was animated by a team of Indigenous and non-Indigenous artists, and produced in partnership with @supply_and_demand_studio

This incredible new experience is free with a Spark Membership or included with a General Admission ticket.

This awe-inspiring and thought-provoking meld of art and science draws the guest in and distorts reality giving new light and perspective on the mundane. Wonderspaces’ mission is to deliver art to new audiences in service to artists, visitors, and team.

Wonderspaces presents extraordinary artwork from around the world in a casual and fun gathering place. This immersive exhibition at Spark features nine interactive, and conversation-provoking works of art and science. Wonderspaces partners with artists to present experiential art shows for all audiences.

Founded in 2016 and headquartered in Los Angeles, @wonderspaces currently presents artwork of over 100 partner artists in Scottsdale, Philadelphia, Austin, San Diego and now Calgary! Grab a coffee ☕️ and your little ones, and head over to CKM and check out the newly renovated nursing room. 👶🏽🍼

Located in the Creative Kids Museum, this space is a quiet oasis for nursing, taking a break with your child or need to change a baby. 

The Creative Kids Museum (CKM) is 10,000 square feet of big fun for Spark’s littlest visitors (ages 0-8) so they can play, build and explore with all their senses!

Kids can explore the water area or create at one of several tactile activity tables. Get comfy in a corner to read a book, make music on the beloved bubble piano or reach new heights inside the climbing adventure space.  

🪶🪶🪶Be sure to check out @themossbagproject too! Guests can get hands-on experience with a real moss bag as you let your little ones feel the materials, and learn how to wrap a baby. It’s a unique opportunity to learn about science that #Indigenous people have known for thousands of years!

CKM is a hub of science for developing brains. 🧠

🧠 The Brainasium at Spark is sure to put some spring in your step!
 
Science isn’t just for rainy days. Open all year, the Brainasium Outdoor Park is selfie-ready, with a 65 foot slide, colorful structures, and lots of things to explore. Neuroscientists know there is a connection between healthy brains and healthy bodies. Physical play helps develop skills like problem solving, spatial thinking and cooperation. Oh, and it is FUN.

🧠 Also starting May 19, the Junkyard Playground is back!  The Junkyard Playground celebrates kids. It’s a space dedicated to children and created by children themselves – with no adults allowed. Weekends only May 19 - June 30.

🪶🌱🌾 In June, the new #Indigenous Gathering Circle will be complete – with a name, new colors, stories and more. In partnership with the Spark Indigenous Advisory Circle and the Indigenous community, a new Gathering Circle has been built as a place to gather and share stories. 

🧠 The Brainasium Outdoor Park is proudly supported by Prairies

💕 The Moss Bag Project is wrapped with love! 💕

#Mothers, #parents, #guardians, and truly everybody, know how important the first few years of a baby's life are for building the #brain.

For centuries, the moss bag has been used by Indigenous mothers and peoples to keep a baby snugly wrapped. It creates a warm, womb-like environment that makes the baby feel safe and sleep better, while the top of the bag holds the head secure, protecting the 🧠.

Check out the permanent moss bag installation at Spark, located in the toddler section of the newly renovated CKM #CreativeKidsMuseum.

@TheMossBagProject is an #Indigenous-led organization that creates sustainable and reciprocal support structures, through academic resources and traditional education. The project offers moss bag making and Indigenous-centered child-rearing education sessions.

#DidYouKnow Moss bags are traditionally made using freshly-gathered sphagnum moss, known to have medicinal properties that made it an ideal diaper? Antiseptic and absorbent, the moss keeps the baby dry and rash-free.

#HappyMothersDay💕

MICROMONUMENTAL MAPPING - THE ESSENCE OF CREATION.

Created by @limelight3dmapping, a group of artists inspired by the Greek Apollo - recognized as a god of music and dance, truth and prophecy, the sun and light - 'The Essence of Creation' conveys this complexity by digitally mapping the symbolic and physical elements of the building.

#Projectionmapping, similar to video mapping and spatial #augmentedreality, is a projection technique that uses a two or three dimensional object to spatially map a virtual program, which then mimics the real environment it is to be projected on.

Did you know #Limelight have been creating #3D #projection #artwork around the world for over 20 years?⁠ Many of their team members have been involved since the birth of #projectionmapping and their work has been shown at light festivals and corporate events around the world.
⁠
📍Micromonumental Mapping, The Essence of Creation can be experienced at TELUS Spark Science Centre and is included with a Spark Membership or General Admission.

🔥Blood orange skies - air quality's claim to flame🔥

The #AirQualityIndex (AQI), is based on the concentration of pollutants present in the air at a particular location. When air quality is good, the air is clear and contains only small amounts of solid particle and chemical pollutants. When the air quality is poor - which contains high levels of pollutants - it is often hazy and dangerous to health, and the environment.

Wildfires release large amounts of carbon dioxide, black carbon, brown carbon, and ozone precursors into the atmosphere. These emissions affect clouds and climate on global scales. Okay, but why the orange sky?

It is because of how different sized particles, scatter light. Relatively larger smoke particles scatter more of the colour spectrum, allowing sunlight's longer wavelength colours - such as red and orange - to filter through, while blocking shorter wavelength colours of yellow, blue and green.

Make sure to stay safe inside today, (say at Spark😉), and protect your lungs! 🫁

Air quality should improve by Wednesday!

#Didyouknow that the shape of your glassware can actually influence the way you taste a cocktail? It's true! The science behind it is called "mouthfeel perception."

🎭🧪🌈 Welcome to Wonderspaces - Where art and science collide!🎭🧪🌈

This immersive exhibition at Spark features nine interactive, and conversation-provoking works of art and science.

TELUS Spark is the first science centre in the world to feature Wonderspaces, and the only place in Canada where these nine artists are showcasing their works.

Check them out:

🎨 Plume by Ian Brill @kianbrill
Plume is a half-dome sculpture that offers an other-wordly audio-visual environment.
📸@cadeventures

🎨 Body Paint by @Memo_Akten
An interactive installation relies on an IR sensor, high powered projector, and custom software to translate movement into splashes of vibrant colour. 
📸@DevonHutchins

🎨 Blooms by @John.Edmark
Dynamic sculptures that combine precise design, high speed rotation and strobe lighting to deliver a surreal optical illusion.

🎨 Sweepers Clock by @Maarten.Baas
Part of the artist’s Real Time Clock Series, Sweepers Clock is a 12-hour film that depicts a pair of workers keeping time by continuously sweeping a pile of garbage in the shape of the hands of a traditional clock.
📸Society Hill Films

🎨 Virata Rupa by Matt Elson @the_infinity_boxes
A box shaped sculpture that offers two different and complementary perspectives on the feeling of infinity.

🎨 The Last Word by @IllegalArt2001
Anonymously write something you may have previously wanted to say but held back on, offering a path to closure and community.

🎨 Micromonumental Mapping by @limelight3dmapping
This audio-visual installation features a five-minute dynamic projection upon a 1:40 scale model of the Lille Opera House. It portrays cycles of creation and destruction.
📸Society Hill Films

🎨 On a Human Scale by @MatthewMatthew
This interactive installation maps a harpsichord’s keys to videos of people singing that note in real-time, creating a unique musical instrument that highlights both our diversity and our shared humanity.

🎨 Thank You Bags by @ReedvanBrunschot
Reed’s Thank You Bags ask us to examine our wastefulness by presenting the iconic symbol of consumerism into a larger-than-life work of art.
📸Society Hill Films

July 1 - A day to reflect and learn.

TELUS Spark Science Centre acknowledges it is situated on the traditional lands of the Niitsitapi (Blackfoot Confederacy), the Tsuut’ina First Nation, the Îethka Nakoda First Nation, and more recently Métis Nation of Alberta Region III. Spark recognizes and supports the depth of science within these lands, languages, stories, and peoples, that have been caretakers of this land, where the Bow and Elbow rivers meet, their home for thousands of years.

This science centre sits within a natural travel, migration, and hunting corridor. It leads people, animals, and weather to the confluence of the Bow and Elbow Rivers, a traditional and current trading and gathering place. Spark is grateful to the peoples who have been caretakers and stewards of this land, allowing us to thrive on this land today, where many cultures and Indigenous people from across Turtle Island, live together in peace and respect.

TELUS Spark is grateful to the Spark Advisory Circle for guiding the development of this land acknowledgement.

Spark is grateful to Elder Casey Eagle Speaker, Sorrel Horse, of Kainai First Nation, for guiding Spark through the development of this land acknowledgement.

Spark encourages learning about the land now called Canada, and the ancestral Indigenous peoples that exist around the globe: https://native-land.ca/

The most obvious sign for a perfect kiss? It's right under your nose. 💋

When humans kiss, the brain releases chemicals oxytocin, dopamine, and serotonin - the rock stars of feel-good neurochemistry!

#Oxytocin is a charismatic chemical that has earned itself the nickname "the love hormone." It strengthens human connection and deepens the emotional bond between smooching partners.

#Dopamine is the mischievous thrill-seeker of the group. This chemical ignites the brain's pleasure centers, creating that grin from ear to ear. it is also responsible for that "thrilling" roller coaster ride of emotions.

#Serotonin is the cheerful mood elevator. Picture this chemical as a joyful sunbeam, casting a radiant glow, and adding an extra sprinkle of happiness to the kissing equation.

So, remember to cherish those brain-tickling, lip-locking moments, and appreciate the chemical circus that unfolds.

Check out #BodyPaint in the #Wonderspaces exhibition! By @memo_akten 

#HappyInternationalKissingDay

Unzipping the Secrets of the Brainasium Outdoor Park.

Did you know that the painted archway tunnel, leading to the tower slide, is actually a zipper!? 🤯

The modern zipper was invented by Gideon Sundback, a Swedish-American engineer, in 1913. Sundback's groundbreaking design revolutionized the way we fasten things, paving the way for easier and more efficient closures.

Real Quick: Why did the zipper go to therapy?
It had closure issues.🤣

Know what doesn't have closure issues? The Brainasium Outdoor Park! It's open year-round, rain or shine! 💦🌞

🍌🐌 GO BANANAS FOR SLUGS! 🐌🍌

Did you know that banana slugs are not only fascinating looking creatures but also vital members of the ecosystem? These slimy superstars steal the show when it comes to their incredible adaptations and ecological importance.

Banana slugs are native to the lush forests of North America and the second-largest species of land slugs in the world. With their bright yellow bodies that can almost reach a foot in length, they certainly stand out! The unique coloration serves as a warning sign to predators, indicating that they're not to be messed with. 💛

They are also not your average garden slug. Banana slugs play a crucial role in nutrient #recycling within their habitats, as they munch on decaying leaves and break down organic matter, returning valuable nutrients back to the soil. Talk about being nature's #composting champions! ♻️

Wanna know how they talk to each other? Banana slugs leave a slime trail behind as they glide along the forest floor. They leave chemical messages in this slime trail that help them navigate and have slimy slug conversations. How cool is that!?

Grab your own #bananaslug this summer from the #sparkstore!

Discover this summer’s hottest micro-organism, the #Tardigrade.

Promoting Artists Redefining Kulture – also known as PARK™️ (@ouronlinepark) is adding to an awesome #summeratSpark with an art-infused Instagrammable structure, PERFECT for the social feed! 📸

This main mural, by Natalia Ionescu (@designedbynatalia), captures the wonder and energy of natural environments. Step, pose and play with the bold shapes and colours with this magnified interpretation of the natural world.

Wanna know something crazy!? Tardigrades (that little pink microorganism on the floor - also known as a 'Water Bear') can survive the harshest conditions. Ever. Like the vacuum of space! They have incredible resiliency and ability to survive extreme conditions - making them the toughest and most resilient creatures known to science.🤯

Tardigrade motto to live by: "I'll be fine."

📸@wired

Take a journey through the different #InfiniteDelightsofSummer designed by #SuminChoi (@itsminpling).

This is interactive piece at #TELUSSpark by Promoting Artists Redefining Kulture – also known as PARK™️ @ouronlinepark - captures the essence of summer’s joy and imagination in the planets of the SUMmer-verse!

Joys like water, and the refreshing plunge on a hot summers day! it's the ultimate way to conquer rising temps. Water is also vital to life - the ocean is where life formed over 3.7 billion years ago after all - but we have yet to discover another planet where BOTH life and water exist together.🏙️ 💦

Enter #exoplanet #GJ1214b. Discovered in 2009, and since the subject of intense study, its atmosphere contains a significant amount of water vapour which has led to the hypotheses that the planet is covered with a deep and dense layer of water.

It is often referred to as a "waterworld", but the conditions on GJ1214b are likely extreme compared to Earth, so probably only #tardigrades could move there.

Did you know that “giving side-eye” is more than just an expression? It’s actually rooted in science!

When you give someone the infamous side-eye, your brain activates a region called the #superiorcolliculus. 
This part of the brain is responsible for processing visual information and directing our gaze.🧠👀

So, when you shoot that sly, sideways glance, your brain is literally sending signals to the eyes to move in that direction, making the side-eye a fascinating blend of body language and neuroscience! 👁️🧠💡

Come to #Spark to check out the Barbie: A Cultural Icon exhibition and see how many side-eyes you can spy!

On until September 10!

Have you discovered the Four Sacred Elements in the newest digital immersion experience at TELUS Spark Science Centre yet?

In a world where harmony with Earth is the ultimate challenge, #sacreddefendersoftheuniverse draws inspiration from the wisdom of ages past.

Before the era of colonization, all living beings coexisted in a symphony of balance, honouring each other's existence through ancient ceremonies and time-honoured traditions.

Today, that delicate balance has been upset by the inner struggle within humanity—an ongoing battle between humility and ego. This timeless conflict, known as The Great Conflict of the Thunderbird and Horned Serpent, echoes through generations.

Walk within the very pages of this story as the narrative unveils the Four Sacred Elements: Water (Aqueous), Fire (Embers), Earth (Terra), and Wind (Aireus). These sacred defenders rekindle the universal gifts of elemental energy, dormant within every human spirit—a legacy inherited from ancient ancestral teachings.

But can the defenders mend the rift between humility and ego before the irreversible effects take their toll on the Earth?

🌌 Makoyoohsokoyi: The Wolf Trail or Milky Way 🌌
 
Star Stories have helped people on these Lands navigate, remember how to live alongside the Land, when to harvest, hunt, and so much more. Now, thanks to @lowhorn.s #makoyoohsokoyi can help teach these stories.
 
The inside and outside of the tunnel depict the landscape and sky at different times of night; dusk and sunset. The black and white trailing marks create the shape of the #wolftrail.
 
The wolves, known as #Makoyiwa, teach humans the importance of living within the circle, and being in relationship with the buffalo and other animals that offer their lives for their survival.🦬
 
The designs on the ceiling of the tunnel are found atop #Blackfoot tipis, the centre symbol representing #Apani, or the butterfly, who is placed there to bring dreams to humans. The seven dots are the Seven Brothers or #bigdipper.
 
When Spring arrives, the wolf eyes (in the Southern Milky Way) disappear, but their teachings remain in the sky as #makoyoohsokoyi. These teachings remind humans how to live in reciprocity with the Land and in the Circle.
 
Did you know one of the Wolf Eyes from the #makoyoohsokoyi story, is actually SagittariusA*, a super massive #Blackhole in the middle of our galaxy?
 
😉 Blackfoot people have known the significance of this location in the sky for thousands of years!

Thanks to Sikapinakii @lowhorn.s for this incredible piece. 💙

🧡 September 30, 2023 is National Day for Truth and Reconciliation.

#NationalDayforTruthandReconciliation is in direct response to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission’s Call to Action 80, which called upon the Government of Canada to establish a National Day for Truth and Reconciliation to honour the Survivors of residential schools. This is a day to reflect and learn about the lasting trauma caused by residential schools.

🧡 What can you do?
Participate in Orange Shirt day. #PhyllisWebstad is the Founder and Ambassador of the Orange Shirt Society. It grew out of Phyllis' story of having her shiny new orange shirt taken away on her first day of school at the Mission residential school, and it has become an opportunity to keep the discussion on all aspects of residential schools happening annually.

Read and learn about the history of residential schools, donate to the Indian Residential School Survivors Society (IRSSS hotline, 1-800-721-0066) and attend an Orange Shirt Day event in your area. Appreciate the strength and resilience of Indigenous people every day. 

Read the TRC and UNDRIP https://bit.ly/46q6CxT  think about how you benefit from Treaty, and how can you give back, to Indigenous communities and to Ancestor Earth.

Spark staff will take the time to honour survivors and the children who never returned home, their families, and communities through special programming taking place from 10:00 AM - 4:00 PM. https://bit.ly/48red0l

🧡 Thank you to to artist #JoeyBigSnake (IG @depressed_danny_devito) for the new artwork that now supports Spark's #LandAcknowledgement, and to Spark's very own (IG @travisburly) for the incredible design of these beautiful orange shirts, and to #LisaBigSnake for the print. 🧡

AND IT BURNS, BURNS, BURNS. THE RING OF FIRE.

A special #ringoffire #annularsolareclipse is happening, and on Saturday October 14, Spark's hosting a viewing party in partnership with our friends at @calgaryrasc!

Spark doors open early at 8:30 AM on Saturday, (Brainasium access only - all other galleries and spaces open at 9 AM) so come down for viewing tips, tricks and special lenses, as well as viewing opportunities of the sun through sun-filtered telescopes from @calgaryrasc as they inform guests as to what they are seeing.

An eclipse like this occurs when the Moon is at its farthest point away from Earth in its elliptical orbit. Because of this increased distance from Earth and human eyes, the apparent size of the Moon is jussst smaller than that of the Sun. So when it passes in front of it, it results in a beautiful ring of fire.

Unfortunately, the “ring of fire” itself won’t be visible to Canadians as the moon won't be lined up perfectly with the Sun. Instead, the partial eclipse (apprx 69.7%) will appear as if a dark shadow has fallen over the side of the Sun, dimming its overall brightness.

All that is needed to attend, is a General Admission ticket!

🦉As long as you don’t have skelephobia, you are going to have a hoot in Steven’s Lab this October!🦉

Dig into a real regurgitated owl pellet to find the skeletal remains of their dinner - plus learn about owl biology along the way! Don’t worry, no owlgebra is required!

Did you know that when our feathered friends grab a bite, they go all-in and swallow their prey whole?

But here's the twist: their digestive system can't handle everything. The owl's version of "table scraps" includes bones, fur, and feathers, which get the boot in the form of... you guessed it, owl pellets! 🦴🦉 After feeding, to safely excrete this material, the owl's gizzard compacts it into a tight pellet that the owl then regurgitates.

When scientists (like you) dive into these pellets, they uncover a treasure trove of clues about the owl's diet. Guests can begin to piece together the puzzle of the owl's menu and the creatures cohabiting in their neck of the woods.

Owl pellets aren't just funky science souvenirs; they're like nature's takeout menus, helping keep tabs on the ecosystem's health, and the ever-changing culinary choices of our wise owl pals!

Head upstairs all October to dig into one yourself!

🌠 WHY DOES A SHOOTING STAR TASTE BETTER THAN A COMET? 🌠

It's a little meteor. ☄️🤣

Get ready to peep one of the most spectacular sights in the night sky - the #Orionids #MeteorShower!

The Orionid meteor shower is active between Sept. 26 to Nov. 22, with peak viewing happening late tomorrow October 20-21, after midnight! Viewing conditions for the Orionids will be 37% illuminated at the time of the peak, meaning it's possible to see up to 20 shooting stars per hour!

Just look to the Constellation of #Gemini, and the Constellation of #Orion to find the best direction to see the shower. (Orion is in the southwestern sky for us Northern Hemispher-ers).

Wanna know something cool? The parent body of the #orionids is the famous #HalleysComet (1P/halley), named after the astronomer Edmund Halley who first made the connection.

So, when you see an Orionid meteor streaking across the night sky, you're witnessing a tiny piece of a famous and ancient celestial traveler, making its presence known from beyond the Earth's atmosphere!

Happy stargazing! ✨ 🔭 🤩

👋 BYE BYE BABY 👋

Spark is saying goodbye to @Wonderspaces, the immersive art and science smash-up, featuring nine interactive and conversation-provoking works.

Explore for the last time, dynamic sculptures, surreal optical illusions, audio-visual environments and interactive installations!

These nine artist works leave Spark Tuesday, October 31.

1. Body Paint by @Memo_Akten
An interactive installation relying on an IR sensor and custom software to translate movement into splashes of vibrant colour.

2. Plume by Ian Brill @kianbrill
Plume is a half-dome sculpture that offers an other-wordly audio-visual environment.
📸 Yadira Villarreal

3. The Last Word by @IllegalArt2001
Anonymously write something you may have previously wanted to say but held back on, offering a path to closure and community.

4. On a Human Scale by @MatthewMatthew
This interactive installation maps a harpsichord’s keys to videos of people singing that note in real-time, creating a unique musical instrument that highlights both our diversity and our shared humanity.

5. Micromonumental Mapping by @limelight3dmapping
This audio-visual installation features a five-minute dynamic projection upon a 1:40 scale model of the Lille Opera House. It portrays cycles of creation and destruction.
📸 Society Hill Films

6. Blooms by @John.Edmark
Dynamic sculptures that combine precise design, high speed rotation and strobe lighting to deliver a surreal optical illusion.

7. Sweepers Clock by @Maarten.Baas
Part of the artist’s Real Time Clock Series, Sweepers Clock is a 12-hour film that depicts a pair of workers keeping time by continuously sweeping a pile of garbage in the shape of the hands of a traditional clock.
📸 Society Hill Films

8. Virata Rupa by Matt Elson @the_infinity_boxes
A box shaped sculpture that offers two different and complementary perspectives on the feeling of infinity.

9. Thank You Bags by @ReedvanBrunschot
Reed’s Thank You Bags ask us to examine our wastefulness by presenting the iconic symbol of consumerism into a larger-than-life work of art.

🎃WITCH-ING YOU A HAPPY HALLOWEEN FROM THE SPARK TEAM! 🎃
Carving faces into vegetables is a tradition that's hundreds of years old, but did you know that pumpkins weren't always the vegetable of choice? 
 
That's right, once upon a time, turnips and other root vegetables like beets were the chosen ones. A scary face would be carved into the root vegetable and placed at the front of the home to scare away evil. 
 
Over time, pumpkins were introduced to the Irish and became the preferred choice for Samhain, which is where Halloween is derived from. It was found that pumpkins are easier to carve and can be hollowed out, which allows for more intricate designs.
 
Traditionally, Samhain celebrations begin on October 31st to mark the end of summer and the start of the darker half of the year. Festivities would often include dressing up to scare away evil spirits, along with the tradition of turnip carving.
From turnip carving to paranormal activities, there’s a world of wild and wacky science waiting to be discovered! Happy Halloween!

🌙 GET IMMERSED IN A CLASSIC BEDTIME TALE!🌙

❇️ A Great Green Room..
🐄 A picture of the cow jumping over the moon..
🧸 Three little bears sitting on chairs.. 
🐱 Two little kittens…and a pair of mittens. 

That’s right, Goodnight Moon by Margaret Wise Brown is back at TELUS Spark! Walk into the classic bedtime story reimagined through an interactive digital experience while learning the science behind sleep. Did you know? REM (rapid eye movement) is the final 10 minutes of the 90 minute sleep cycle. Getting quality REM sleep improves the brains ability to consolidate and process new information. ✨

The Digital Immersion Gallery is open for visitors to explore and find all the answers to sleep-related science questions. Plus, take a selfie with cozy life-size props, paint the Great Green Room, and sit down to enjoy the fabulous bedtime story. 
Don't miss out – gather your friends and family to come and enjoy the magic of Goodnight Moon. The Digital Immersion Gallery can be accessed with General Admission or included with a Spark Membership!

🥼🧪IN SCIENCE WE TRUST🧫
 
November 10 is World Science Day for Peace and Development. This special day highlights the important role of science in society and the need to engage the wider public in debates on emerging scientific issues. It also underlines the importance and relevance of science in our daily lives.
 
The theme for 2023 is: Building trust in science.
 
The role of science in shaping our collective future can only be fulfilled when there is trust in science. It is trust in science that fuels the development and application of evidence-based solutions to our world’s multifaceted challenges. Trust in science is a complex issue. It affects the way in which scientists operate and the way science is perceived by society. Also, enhancing trust in science strengthens science-based policy decisions and society’s support for their application.
 
💕🥼🧠We have seen countless examples in how science has changed the world. For more information please check out @unesco #scienceday

🏳️‍🌈 Today is International day of 2sLGBTQIA+ in STEM! 🏳️‍🌈 

Spark proudly celebrates and welcomes 2sLGBTQIA+ into the science community and is committed to being a inclusive space for everyone. Did you know? Over 20% of 2sLGBTQIA+ people had considered leaving jobs in STEM due to work place discrimination. Let’s break down barriers and create a safe path for marginalized people to pursue a career in STEM!

Want to help, celebrate or participate?
🏳️‍🌈Boost voices of 2sLGBTQIA+ in STEM!
🏳️‍🌈Learn about 2sLGBTQIA+ people in STEM like George Washington Carver (pioneering agricultural scientist), @ChemicalKim (chemistry professor and stem educator) and Sara Josephine Baker (medical physician).
🏳️‍🌈Are you 2sLGBTQIA+ in STEM? Share your story if comfortable. 

Did you know ‘2s’ in 2sLGBTQIA+ stands for Two-Spirit? This is an indigenous term that refers to somebody who embodies both masculine and feminine qualities or gender roles. The concept and term varies across different nations.

#LGBTSTEMDay #LGBTQSTEMDay

✨ 🎁 GIVE THE GIFT OF SCIENCE 🎁 ✨ 
Last year, Spark’s school programs alone engaged some 82,000 eager minds in a variety of areas of focus. The science centre is the place where young scientists are often born.

The fact is, less than ¼ of all Canadian graduates in 2020 were from STEAM programs resulting in a shortage of new skilled STEAM graduates to fill the exploding job demand for big problem solvers.

This is why your donation to Spark this month is so important. Your gift of science... your investment... will provide this critical opportunity for even more young people to see themselves as learners, innovators, and solution-finders and help unlock their potential.

Your donation will enable Spark to:
✨ Expand educational programs to reach even more students
✨ Develop cutting-edge exhibits and experiences to inspire the next generation of scientists and innovators
✨ Support initiatives aimed at creating more STEM graduates in Canada
This holiday season, give a gift that will change a life, make a difference, and inspire the future generation of problem solvers to build a better world for all of us. Give the gift of science!

🌟 Happy Giving Tuesday! 🌟 Give the Gift of Science✨
TELUS Spark is Calgary’s science centre!

For over 55 years, Calgary’s science centre has been a pillar in educating and immersing audiences in the fascinating world of science and technology. It’s been a beacon of innovation, a hub for curious minds to explore and a place for hundreds of thousands of people to come together. When Spark recently asked the community what they need out of their local science centre, they answered, “we want more.”

Keeping Calgary Curious through Re-imagined Spaces, Innovative and Inspired Programs and being Welcoming to All.

We could not do all we do without help and support. Spark currently has 86 community partners that help with hosting guests at Spark that could not otherwise attend, all funded by generous sponsors, is part of the Fair Access program through the City of Calgary and hosts over 70,000 students yearly! Through multiple ways of knowing science, partnering with community for events and programs and Spark hosts over 400,000 guests yearly.

Until Dec 31, 2023, the Nicholls family matches all donations up to $100,000!
